name.text: Coordinate Transformation: Rotating Axes and Finding New Coordinates

questiontext.text:
Given that the \(xy\)-coordinate axes have undergone a \({@angle@}^{\circ}\) counterclockwise rotation about the origin to establish the new \(x'y'\)-coordinate system, determine the coordinates of the following points in relation to the \(x’y’\)-system:

Note: \( x' = x \cos(\theta) - y \sin(\theta) \\ y' = x \sin(\theta) + y \cos(\theta) \) Where \(\theta\) is the angle of rotation, which is \({@angle@}^{\circ}\) in this case.

Calculate the coordinates in the \(x’y’\)-system for each of the following points:

  1. \(({@points_xy[1][1]@},{@points_xy[1][2]@})\) \(\begin{pmatrix}x' \\ y' \end{pmatrix}=\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]
  2. \(({@points_xy[2][1]@},{@points_xy[2][2]@})\) \(\begin{pmatrix}x' \\ y' \end{pmatrix}=\) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:prt2]]
  3. \(({@points_xy[3][1]@},{@points_xy[3][2]@})\) \(\begin{pmatrix}x' \\ y' \end{pmatrix}=\) [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]] [[feedback:prt3]]
  4. \(({@points_xy[4][1]@},{@points_xy[4][2]@})\) \(\begin{pmatrix}x' \\ y' \end{pmatrix}=\) [[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]] [[feedback:prt4]]
  5. \(({@points_xy[5][1]@},{@points_xy[5][2]@})\) \(\begin{pmatrix}x' \\ y' \end{pmatrix}=\) [[input:ans5]] [[validation:ans5]] [[feedback:prt5]]

generalfeedback.text:
Worked Solution

When rotating the coordinate axes counterclockwise by \({@angle@}^{\circ}\), you are performing a coordinate transformation using rotation matrices.

The rotation matrix for a counterclockwise rotation by an angle \(\theta\) is:

\( R(\theta) = \begin{pmatrix} \cos (\theta) & -\sin (\theta) \\ \sin (\theta) & \cos (\theta) \end{pmatrix} \)

This rotates column vectors by means of the following matrix multiplication: \( \begin{pmatrix} x' \\ y' \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} \)

In this case, since the angle \(\theta\) is \({@angle@}^{\circ}\), we have:

\( R(\theta) = \begin{pmatrix} \cos ({@angle@}^{\circ}) & -\sin ({@angle@}^{\circ}) \\ \sin ({@angle@}^{\circ})& \cos ({@angle@}^{\circ}) \end{pmatrix} = {@rotation_matrix@} \)

To find the coordinates of points relative to the new \(x'y'\)-system, you multiply the rotation matrix by the original coordinates. Let's go through each point:

  1. Point \(({@points_xy[1][1]@},{@points_xy[1][2]@})\):

    \(\begin{pmatrix}x' \\ y' \end{pmatrix}= {@rotation_matrix@}\begin{pmatrix}{@points_xy[1][1]@}\\ {@points_xy[1][2]@}\end{pmatrix}=\begin{pmatrix}{@p[1]@} \\ {@p[2]@}\end{pmatrix}\) Coordinates in \(x'y'\)-system: \(\left({@p[1]@}, {@p[2]@}\right)\)

  2. Point \(({@points_xy[2][1]@},{@points_xy[2][2]@})\):

    \(\begin{pmatrix}x' \\ y' \end{pmatrix}= {@rotation_matrix@}\begin{pmatrix}{@points_xy[2][1]@}\\ {@points_xy[2][2]@}\end{pmatrix}=\begin{pmatrix}{@p[3]@} \\ {@p[4]@}\end{pmatrix}\) Coordinates in \(x'y'\)-system: \(\left({@p[3]@}, {@p[4]@}\right)\)

  3. Point \(({@points_xy[3][1]@},{@points_xy[3][2]@})\):

    \(\begin{pmatrix}x' \\ y' \end{pmatrix}= {@rotation_matrix@}\begin{pmatrix}{@points_xy[3][1]@}\\ {@points_xy[3][2]@}\end{pmatrix}=\begin{pmatrix}{@p[5]@} \\ {@p[6]@}\end{pmatrix}\) Coordinates in \(x'y'\)-system: \(\left({@p[5]@}, {@p[6]@}\right)\)

  4. Point \(({@points_xy[4][1]@},{@points_xy[4][2]@})\):

    \(\begin{pmatrix}x' \\ y' \end{pmatrix}= {@rotation_matrix@}\begin{pmatrix}{@points_xy[4][1]@}\\ {@points_xy[4][2]@}\end{pmatrix}=\begin{pmatrix}{@p[7]@} \\ {@p[8]@}\end{pmatrix}\) Coordinates in \(x'y'\)-system: \(\left({@p[7]@}, {@p[8]@}\right)\)

  5. Point \(({@points_xy[5][1]@},{@points_xy[5][2]@})\):

    \(\begin{pmatrix}x' \\ y' \end{pmatrix}= {@rotation_matrix@}\begin{pmatrix}{@points_xy[5][1]@}\\ {@points_xy[5][2]@}\end{pmatrix}=\begin{pmatrix}{@p[9]@} \\ {@p[10]@}\end{pmatrix}\) Coordinates in \(x'y'\)-system: \(\left({@p[9]@}, {@p[10]@}\right)\)

These are the coordinates of the given points relative to the new \(x'y'\)-coordinate system after rotating the \(xy\)-coordinate axes \({@angle@}^{\circ}\) counterclockwise about the origin.

questionnote.text:
Given that the \(xy\)-coordinate axes have undergone a \({@angle@}^{\circ}\)

  1. \({@points_xy[1]@}\)
    \((x' y')={@ta1@}\)
  2. \({@points_xy[2]@}\)
    \((x' y')={@ta2@}\)
  3. \({@points_xy[3]@}\)
    \((x' y')={@ta3@}\)
  4. \({@points_xy[4]@}\)
    \((x' y')={@ta4@}\)
  5. \({@points_xy[5]@}\)
    \((x' y')={@ta5@}\)

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

truefeedback.text:
Be cautious of sign errors in the rotation matrix; ensure correct application of signs during multiplication to avoid incorrect values and directions in transformed coordinates.

In two dimensions, the standard rotation matrix has the following form: \[ R(\theta) = \begin{bmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{bmatrix}. \] This rotates column vectors by means of the following matrix multiplication: \[ \begin{bmatrix} x' \\ y' \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix}. \] Thus, the new coordinates \(x', y')\) of a point \(x, y)\) after rotation are given by: \[ \begin{aligned} x' &= x \cos \theta - y \sin \theta, \\ y' &= x \sin \theta + y \cos \theta. \end{aligned} \]
